title: Real estate giant Grant Cardone is selling his Miami mansion with 7 bedrooms for 400 Bitcoin
description: Real estate mogul Grant Cardone has listed his $42M Miami beach mansion for 400 Bitcoin only — no cash accepted.
content:
Real estate mogul Grant Cardone has listed his $42M Miami beach mansion for 400 Bitcoin only — no cash accepted.

Grant Cardone has never been one to play small. The real estate mogul, author, and motivational speaker built an empire with Cardone Capital, controlling billions in multifamily properties across the U.S.

He’s sold out arenas, coached entrepreneurs, and turned himself into a brand synonymous with aggressive growth. Now, he’s putting that same bold approach to work in crypto.

Cardone has long flirted with Bitcoin as an asset class, praising its potential as a hedge against inflation. And in true Cardone fashion, he’s not dipping a toe into the space — he’s cannonballing. This week, he listed his luxury oceanfront mansion in Golden Beach, Miami, with a price tag denominated entirely in Bitcoin.

“605 Ocean Blvd – Listed for Sale BTC ONLY – Trying to catch the DIP. Best Ocean Front Beach Entry in ALL of Miami. Quick Sale 400 BTC,” Cardone posted on X to his 720,000 followers.

The listing, shared via Propy and realtor platforms, features a 13,000+ square foot home with seven bedrooms, 12 bathrooms, an infinity pool, a private beachfront cabana, and a gourmet kitchen kitted with Subzero and Gaggenau appliances.

Designed by Martyn Lawrence Bullard and even featured in Architectural Digest, the estate is pure Miami glamour — glass, marble, saltwater pool, skylights, and 100 feet of private ocean frontage.

The ask: Well, 400 BTC.

At today’s Kraken's price of about $107,700 per Bitcoin, that comes to roughly $43 million. The realtor listing pegs it at $42 million, making Cardone’s math pretty spot on.

At 400 BTC, the mansion locks in at today’s spot rate. But here’s the wrinkle: historically, Bitcoin has delivered returns far beyond real estate.
• Five years ago, 400 BTC would have cost around $1.5 million total. Today, that stash is worth more than $43 million.
• Over the past 12 months alone, Bitcoin has climbed about 80%, outpacing most real estate markets.
• The all-time high of Bitcoin, just a few weeks ago in August 2025, hit $124,128. At that price, Cardone’s ask would equal nearly $50 million.

So, is it worth swapping Bitcoin for Miami marble?

The answer depends on your view. If Bitcoin continues its historic trajectory, the buyer might one day regret parting with 400 BTC for a mansion. On the other hand, it’s a hedge: real estate provides utility, lifestyle, and a tangible store of value — things Bitcoin doesn’t.
